Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 221.40, up 34.8 (+18.65%), High: 224.00, Low: 215.20, Volume: 2.48m

Firm offer and increased ratio ahead of the 5pm TP deadline.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Offering a 0.168x exchange ratio, so a 10% premium to the indicative offer of 0.153x from May.

BE11:23am

So .......... all done? Yeah, probably. Here's Berenberg.

BE11:23am

Implied valuation: Given that the Barrick share price has increased significantly since the indicative offer was made, we calculate that the updated offer now implies a 231p valuation for Acacia. This represents a 24% premium to Acacia’s closing price yesterday, and a 53% premium to the undisturbed price from 20 May (prior to the indicative offer) and finally, a 28% premium to the 20-day VWAP.
● Acceptable level: We previously wrote that an increased exchange ratio would be the most sensible outcome for both the minority holders and Barrick (which seemed keen to for the deal not to fail, as this would have resulted in international arbitration being the next best way to recover value). We assume that the increased offer level will now be acceptable to the minority shareholders, and note that the Acacia directors have unanimously approved the acquisition.
● North Mara risk: Last Friday’s announcement that the North Mara mine cannot export its gold production until the Tanzanian Mining Commission inspects the mine, in conjunction with the news this week that the government has issued a prohibition notice on the use of the mine’s tailings storage facility (TSF), led us to believe the mine is on the brink of announcing a temporary closure. Given that the mine makes up 70% of the group’s 2019 production guidance, this news would have a serious impact on its financial position. As a result of the risk relating to North Mara’s ability to continue operations, we would expect minority shareholders to support the offer.
● Valuation and recommendation: Our 224p price target and Hold recommendation remain unchanged. However, we expect shares to rally strongly today, thereafter trading in line with the Barrick share price. We are pleased to see an increased exchange ratio, which is broadly in line with our own valuation. It is worth noting that, at spot gold (USD1,440/oz), our valuation rises to 305p which is based on a 230p NAV and 380p EV/EBITDA valuation.
● Next steps: The acquisition will be conditional on the approval of shareholders, regulatory clearances and the court sanctioning the scheme of arrangement. This is all likely to close (if approved by shareholders) by Q4 2019.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Ditto Panmure.

BE11:24am

We see a high probability of completion to this deal, especially given the additional pressure recently being exerted by the Tanzanian Government. ... Despite the extremely hostile operating environment, Acacia continued to deliver on its stated targets. However, given the ongoing uncertainty and discount applied to the Acacia portfolio as per the original Barrick approach, the shares continued to trade at a material discount to our normalised intuitive multiple of 1.0x NAV. We see the positive revision as a result of the recent resource and reserve upgrades and revised economic assessment of the Acacia portfolio.

[I]n light of the high level of recent activity in the Colombian E&P sector, it has decided to conduct a formal review of the various strategic options available to the Company to maximise value for shareholders.

Soundbuy @ nichoman - perhaps..........@1966AndAllThat - short straw for the skunks then.......
BE11:33am

....... let me find some hypothetical values here. Stifel have gone suspended this morning so let's scan back to what they said previously.

BE11:33am

Amerisur is a debt-free, stable cash generator producing oil from three fields across two licences onshore Colombia. The investment thesis is simple: recycle $35-45M of annual operating cash flow into a mixture of short and long-cycle exploration-led reinvestment opportunities.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Continuous H2 2019 drilling programme in CPO-5: We carry the exploration &
appraisal upside at CPO-5 at 18p/shr risked in our 37p NAV (70p unrisked; Figure 1).
The attraction of the licence is: (i) moderate geological risk (75% success rate to date),
(ii) rapid discovery-to-monetisation timeline, a matter of days/weeks, and (iii) benign, lowcost
operating environment both in terms of capex, opex and oil exports.
• Appraisal up next, could add 20% to group production: As previously announced, the next well at CPO-5 will be appraisal of the Indico discovery, with a result expected in ~August (Indico-2). Prior wells have flowed 3-5 kb/d (gross); at the mid-point and net to AMER's 30% working interest, the contribution to group revenue of a success would therefore be around 20% of our estimate of underlying FY19 group production (5.9 kb/d).
• H2 2019 activity on the block could add ~50% to group reserves: The schedule beyond Indico-2 is yet to be determined, but success at the well might encourage further back-to-back drilling on the structure. Indico's upside is c.50M bbls (70 vs current 2P of 23), so, net to 30% working interest, adds of ~15M bbls would equate to ~50% of group reserves.
• Sol testing to complete first: Amerisur expects to wrap up testing of the Sol well in the next couple of weeks. As announced on June 17, the well found 27 feet of net pay, which is some way below the two other successes in the block (100 ft +). Nevertheless, the commercial threshold here is low, and we would expect the well to be put into commercial production even were it to achieve a rate of a few hundred barrels per day.
Production guide reiterated; we are top end: 2019E guidance of 5-6 kb/d looks achievable vs. June daily production 6.8 kb/d, despite a modest first quarter that saw 5M production average 5.3 kb/d. Current guidance excludes any exploration success.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Publicis reported another disappointing quarter on organic growth and lowered FY organic growth guidance, mainly reflecting ongoing attrition in US creative. 2Q19 organic growth of 0.1% (1Q19: -1.8%) missed GSe/company-compiled consensus forecasts of 0.5%/0.7% despite the benefit of account wins and 370bp easy comps. The company attributes this to the US, which was down -1.7% (GSe/cons: -0.5%), which contrasts with OMC’s reported +3.2% and a weak performance in Brazil (-20%). However, 1H EBITA margins of 15.0% excl. transaction costs (+60bp yoy) were 30bp ahead of GSe/consensus reflecting greater cost savings and a 20bp benefit from IFRS 16. As a result, FY organic growth guidance was lowered to broadly stable compared to previous guidance of higher organic growth in 2019 vs 2018 (ZoneFinance consensus: 0.9%). Margin expansion is now expected to be at the lower end of the 30-50bp range, given the dilutive impact of Epsilon as well as €20m higher restructuring costs.
While the stock has already underperformed the Stoxx 600 by 16% YTD, we believe these results will be taken negatively by the market given the weaker organic growth and outlook. We also see a slightly negative read across for WPP which is facing similar challenges in its US creative business.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And Kepler off the call.

BE11:40am

Organic growth back to positive, but only just
Q2 revenues came in at EUR2,234m, slightly below our forecast of
EUR2,296m (consensus EUREUR2,247m) due to slightly lower-thanforecast
organic growth (+0.1% vs +1.3% KECH, +0.7% consensus) and a
low level of net M&A (PHS and ProxiMedia were disposed of in H1).
North America again the main problem region
North America was once again the main drag by region, declining -1.7% (vs
our forecast of flat) as a small number of large FMCG clients continued to
cut fees, meaning attrition weighed -300bp on organic growth in the
region and cEUR50m at a group level in Q2. Europe, where the country
model is more established, continue to grow for the 4th successive quarter
(by +2.4% vs +0.8% in Q1), albeit off an easy comp (-3.6%), and Asia-PAC
also accelerated (from +1.2% to +2.7%), despite negative growth in China,
Japan, Indonesia and Australia (India and Singapore grew double-digit).
Strong performance on margins thanks to savings
Adjusted operating profit, excluding transaction costs relating to Epsilon
(consolidated from July onwards), was slightly higher than forecast, at
EUR652m versus EUR640m KECH (consensus EUR640m), which
constituted 5.7% growth YOY and 60bp of margin improvement, of which
+20bp related to IFRS 16 and +50bp forex and disposals. This was driven
by EUR108m of additional cost savings in H1 through streamlining (Power
of One), of which EUR48m was reinvested in Talent and game-changer
activities, whose revenues reached EUR580m, 13% of group revenue, in
H1, up 24% YOY (+21% YOY in Q2). The margin growth was achieved
despite an increase in above-the-line restructuring costs (to EUR61m in H1
vs. EUR36m in H1 2018), and are guided to reach EUR60-70m in H2,
versus EUR68m in H2 2018.
Lower 2019/20 EPS by 1-2% only, having raised post-Epsilon
The company lowered its FY guidance from (unspecified) growth to flat,
driving us to lower our forecast from +0.6% to -0.2%. Margin growth
targets of 30-50bp YOY are maintained, though at the lower end of the
range. At this includes (lower-margin) Epsilon, this is actually slightly more
than we were previously forecasting, limiting EPS cuts to 1-2% for
2019/20. We leave our TP, based on based on the mean of 15-year average
EV/EBITA (10.5) and the 15-year low (8.3x), unchanged.

Tom Dalgleish @48, would you be a buyer of UK shopping centres? Have they plumbed bottom?
BE11:41am

And Liberum.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

While we like the Agencies in general, and the impact of the downgrades is quite limited, it is clear that management do not have a full grasp on what is happening and that makes us cautious about recommending clients to Buy. For longer-term investors looking for agency exposure, we recommend WPP. Our new TP is €47.60, which is based on a 10x FY19E adjusted PE multiple.

red @Tom Dalgleishnot yet, as not at bottom yet.
BE11:42am

Miss on the guidance – not for the first time

Q2 organic revenue was +0.1% vs Lib est. +0.5 and consensus +0.7%. North America was weak (-1.7% in Q2, -3% in 1H). Publicis stated that “fee reductions in traditional advertising continued to impact our US operations by almost 300 basis points in the second quarter“ blaming clients cutting budgets as they faced pressures of their own and also the impact of Publicis’ own restructuring (Publicis recently announced a reorganisation of their North American business into geographical segments). Operating margin ex-restructuring costs rose 60bps yoy to 15%.

Plato the Cook @Tom D>: bottom will be when they become something other than shopping centres
Tom Dalgleish Thnx Red, reason I ask is Oz is behind the decline curve so naturally wondering over here
BE11:43am

Actual changes to numbers not really that much despite the downgrades…

Publicis took its organic net revenue target for FY19 from above 2018’s +0.8% to broadly flat.

red @Plato the Cookfor many not commercially viable to convert. so may need to be sold off/ go bust and someone else gets any upside from those new levels
11:43 am
BE11:43am

We drop our estimates from +1% to flat. However, the impact on

BE11:43am

the bottom line is limited [0.2%] with Publicis seemingly making up the ground at the earnings level by better cost control management. The company reiterated a 30-50bps increase in operating margin yoy and a 5%-10% increase in adjusted EPS.

BE11:43am

…but that is not the point

Operationally, the weakness in North America is the biggest concern given (1) Publicis is the strongest player in North American media buying, which should be the highest margin part of the business and (2) we now have two major agencies (WPP and Publicis) both having weakness in North America, which raises questions as to what is happening in this particular market. Until we feel more comfortable that there are no more unexpected downgrades coming through, we think it is best to downgrade to HOLD (from BUY) and base our Target Price on a 10x adjusted FY19E PE multiple, which gives €47.6.

Tom Dalgleish Because shopping centres never did cannabalise each other in the upswing Im cautiously optimistic it wont be as bad here
red @Tom Dalgleisheurope same. still building em here in poland. slightly diff economics but eventually they will all get there
Irish HF guy @red, Tom D Intu hit 80p up from low of 74p. Yield is 7.7% based on current price and rent roll staying as is. Lower rents in future = lower share price

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Glencore? Yeah, sure. Goldman selling.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 268.90, down 0.75 (-0.28%), High: 271.70, Low: 266.50, Volume: 8.49m
Tom Dalgleish @Irish, aggregate competitors?
BE11:57am

We downgrade Glencore to Sell (from Neutral) on a relative basis versus our mining coverage with a reduced 12-month price target of 240p (was 310p, implying 11% downside) solely on the back of our estimate changes.
Glencore has underperformed since mid-April 2019 with the shares down 20% vs BHP, Rio and Anglo up 5% on average. This has been largely due to Glen’s commodity basket, which has underperformed (mainly coal, down 30-50% ytd and cobalt down 50% ytd) while iron ore is up 67% ytd, leading to diverging consensus earnings paths (Glen cons 2019 EBITDA down 16% vs an average increase in BHP, Rio and Anglo of 22%). All consensus from Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
Despite the 2019 underperformance, we downgrade to Sell ahead of the 2Q production report and 1H19 results as we expect the issues that have caused the underperformance to persist into 2H19. We see i) no imminent improvement in the commodity basket with the risk that coal is facing further headwinds as onshore China coal price dips below Rmb600 / t; ii) another weakish production report implying a ~20% improvement in production in 2H to hit FY guidance, and iii) the DoJ case as continuing to be an overhang. We reduce our 2019 EBITDA estimate by 10% to $11.9bn, which is 11% below consensus, so we see continued negative consensus earnings revisions. We also lower our 2020 EBITDA by 15% to $12.6bn.

Tom Dalgleish @Red, execution aside I agree
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Beyond the earnings revisions, Glencore’s valuation is not as compelling as it was in the 2016-18 period. The shares are trading at 5.5x 2019E EV/EBITDA on our revised 2019 EBITDA estimate vs. an average of 3.7x in 2018; Rio and Anglo American trade at 5x and 4x, respectively, both below their long-term averages.

undefined
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR - enjoy the weekend.
BE11:59am

Coverage of Asos, post the umpteenth warning, is as mixed as you'd expect.

11:59 am
ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 2,144, up 37 (+1.76%), High: 2,179, Low: 2,033, Volume: 1.04m
red @Tom Dalgleishdisney starting the journey with huge content box while netflix ever increasing spend and law of averages says it will run across a few expensive duds
BE11:59am

Barclays has chucked in the towel.

Tom Dalgleish @BE, a view applicable to all diversified miners
BE11:59am

It became apparent that ASOS was struggling with several issues, most notably warehouse transition, when it warned last December. But we stayed Overweight on the thesis that better growth would materialise in 2H FY19, driven by EU automation and improvements to the customer proposition in the US (the latter being the key to the bull case). Neither has happened –rather,they are the root cause of this warning. Our confidence is therefore significantly reduced. On paper the issues in EU and US should be fixable with time given the problem is inventory-led and not consumer-driven. But we may not seeevidence until cal Q4 at least, and before then we have to get through FY results in Oct. Witha relatively new Chairman and a new CFO, visibility is almost non-existentas to how they might guide for FY20E. We don’t view the shares as cheap enough to fully compensate for the risk,so we downgradeto Equal Weight. We cut forecasts 20%+and ourPT falls 35% to2,750

red which means while sp will almost certainly bounce back, you will get a heavy heavy hit sometime in future
Blank canvas 12.00 Thanks for everything this week BE. It's been a gold-plated, copper-bottomed sterling performance
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

The bull case from here. We are still of the view that there is a big opportunity in the US. If inventory issues are fixed, consumer demand is there. Management could still conceivably deliveronthe promise of a return to a 4% margin,with growth accelerating to 20% in FY20/21/22E. Upside EPS of c175p in FY22E -13x P/Etoday.Putting 25x on that upside EPS and discounting back yields 3,700p as an upside.We are still inclined to see this as an achievable scenario –but we lack confidence.The bear case from here. The second warning (despite a sense that the bar had been set deliberately low back in December) has further weakened confidence. Operational issues could conceivably persist into 2020. Management could step away from a marginrecovery, focusing everything on growth. It could also look at an equity raise (though they aren’t suggesting that for now). Ecomm names with more challenged structural stories trade on 0.4x sales or below –still greater than 30% downsidefrom 0.6x now.So even if we take a view there is still value longer term, things could get worse from here

Tom Dalgleish can Disney outgun Netflix
BE12:00pm

They suggest Delivery Hero as on the same valuation but doing better growth.

BE12:01pm

Credit Suisse is more optimistic.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Is it a broken business? Without seeing GM by division it’s hard to be
certain; however, the 16% sales growth P3 for the UK and RoW operations,
and the performance of Asos Design, would seem to suggest that most of the
problems are in US and Europe and infrastructure/transition related. That the
origins of the problems at P1, 1H and now P3 are all seemingly quite
different would seem to suggest that management is struggling to cope with
the record pace of change both within its own business, and across the
market as a whole. So we welcome the intention of strengthening the
management team, even if it might be more than 6 months off before they arrive.

BE12:01pm

Is the balance sheet an issue? FY net debt is now guided to c£100m (vs
£50m), and we assume that debt typically peaks twice a year (March and
October) at £60-80m above the FY number. With net debt potentially peaking
at £180m that could have been a problem with the previous £150m facility.
However, with £350m they should have plenty of headroom on. On
covenants, we forecast EBITDA of £103m (3.8%) and given that typical
covenants might be c3x there should be plenty of scope, even at current
margins.

BE12:01pm

What catalyst? Beyond fleshing out the numbers, P4 sales and FY profits
are unlikely to reassure materially. 19/20 guidance is clearly of interest, but
Asos is likely to be a “show me” stock until at least 1H 19/20. We are cutting
current PTP to £30m, in line with guidance, and expect 100bp improvement
to EBIT margins to 2.2% in 19/20. This should prove cautious that most of
this year’s £47m (1.2% of sales) of transition costs should roll off. We are
cutting the target price to £34.5 (vs £41.0) based on 1.2x EV/sales, DCF with
5% terminal margin and 20x EV/EBITDA. We estimate the current share
price discounts a 3% terminal margin which should be very achievable,
although the risks are that this year’s profit warnings mask a bigger
underlying issue with the Asos brand appeal or the underlying model.

Tom Dalgleish complexity seems to get the better of many apparel retailers
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Asos is considered higher quality than the 10,000 online frock shops that sell stuff on Facebook and in the ad breaks on Love Island, right?

BE12:03pm

Though I guess it all comes from the same wallet share.

undefined
Excel Developer that OBR report ignores the unicorn trade deals we're waiting to sign.
1966AndAllThat @BE not convinced ROTR is Live Island Target audience. Apprentice maybe
Tom Dalgleish Easy way to wealth is to start a business in a gold mining town during a boom which may be now. Kalgoorlie here I come!!!
Excel Developer @BE: Sorry I'm late, by the way isn't "wallet share" institutionally sexist?
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Oh, and while on fashion. Morgan Stanley saying Buy Dunkerton, sell the absence of Kelvin.

BE12:05pm

We see Ted Baker and Superdry as ‘Brands’, rather than ‘Retailers’. Both are also now ‘recovery stories’. We think Superdry offers the more attractive investment proposition, and see Ted Baker as fairly valued. Initiate on Superdry at Overweight and Ted Baker at Equal-weight. We see Ted Baker and Superdry as Brands, not Retailers. Whilst online channel shift continues to pose significant challenges for traditional retailers, neither Ted Baker nor Superdry is burdened by onerous lease commitments. We estimate that less than 25% of their Global Gross Merchandise Value last year came from sales generated in company-owned stores. Instead they rely on Wholesale, Franchise, Concession and Licensing income – revenue sources that depend primarily on the strengths of their product ranges and their brands.Both have seen big share price declines over the last 18 months … Since the beginning of 2018, Ted Baker and Superdry have seen their share prices fall by 70% and 77%, respectively. Although there have been significant downgrades, both are now trading at c10x P/E – low multiples for stocks that have delivered PBT CAGRs of 13% (Ted Baker) and 35% (Superdry) in ten years prior to this year. … but we do not believe either brand is ‘broken’. New AlphaWise data supports our view that neither brand has become ‘irrelevant’. Brand perception, at least in the UK, has remained relatively stable year over year.We view Superdry as the more attractive investment proposition … We believe Superdry's issues have been largely self-inflicted. Having met with Julian Dunkerton (the company’s founder, who recently returned to the business) following the preliminary results, we are hopeful that the business can be put back on track within a couple of seasons. If this proves possible, the shares could be worth as much as 2,100p (our bull case). We set our price target rather lower at 890p. Nevertheless we see the risk-reward as very attractive; given that the company has a robust balance sheet we believe even in a bear case scenario the shares would be worth 140p.… and Ted Baker as fairly valued. Whereas the founder has just returned at Superdry, the opposite is true at Ted Baker (Ray Kelvin resigned in March). Combined with a lack of potential positive catalysts, we think this makes the Ted Baker story the less appealing of the two over the next 12-18 months.Where could we be wrong? Fixing the Superdry brand could take longer than we anticipate, or may not be possible at all. Ted Baker could reaccelerate and concerns around the US environment may be misplaced (bull case 2,600p). Or Ray Kelvin's resignation may lead to trading weakening further (bear case 400p).
